column4: I partitioned linux in a 10gig ext3 but left 115 gigs in a fat32 so that both windows and linux can access it
but i cant make links on my linux desktop to anything in the FAT32 area, which is problematic
Right i want them to access the same files
So its correct to set up my external HD with 10 gig for linux, 500 meg swap, 115 gig fat32 free space?
Partitioning is easy, i do that from my boot cd
right
i just dont get why i cant make shortcuts to thing s in Fat32... it says "error - wrong file system"
All i want is links on my desktop the same way youd do them in windows, giving you quick access to frequently used files
Oh they have those?
You can make windows read ext3?
yes you can
like we can't be expected to know what a hal.dll or a system32 directory is ;)
so anyway, you have the Ubuntu CD but you can't boot it because you can only boot from floppies? is that it?
well what command prompt should you have?
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SmartBootManagerHowto
this will allow you to boot the Ubuntu CD using a floppy disk
so you only have network?
then netboot it is, but you need another computer
what about a USB key?
doesn't matter, you can still boot from a floppy
use https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SmartBootManagerHowto to boot from a floppy, and then follow the installing from USB howto for the rest
or use netinstall, but somehow i think that's harder

this is the USB howto: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Installation/FromUSBStick  -  i guess you just need to skip the parts about making it bootable, and use the smart boot manager on a floppy instead

oh there's also this one that tells you how to boot from USB when USB is not bootable... using a CD, however. but i guess it would work with a floppy as well, with little changes (but i'd try the smart boot manager route first) https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BootFromUSB
